title: New molecular tools for the next generation of solar microbial cell factories
content: Cyanobacteria have the characteristic ability to perform oxygenic photosynthesis. This capacity to capture CO2 makes them an attractive chassis for solar energy–driven microbial cell factories to produce useful biomolecules. In fact, model cyanobacterial strains, such as Synechocystis sp. PCC 6803, Synechococcus elongatus PCC 7942, and Synechococcus sp. PCC 7002, have been engineered to manufacture commodity products such as biofuels, natural food additives, and terpenoids (Bühler and Lindberg 2023). For industrial setups, highly productive, fast-growing strains are particularly attractive and have potential to increase yields, thus lowering production costs (Selão 2022). However, molecular tools are largely lacking for these fast-growing strains to engineer them into cellular factories.
